title: Can I write 'meself' instead of 'myself'? - Quora

response.answer_text: You just did. What’s more, people will understand you most of the time, or at least assume you have just made a simple spelling mistake. If you are writing in a particular dialect in which “meself” feels more appropriate, then people may appreciate the ‘colour’ of the spelling. As an alternative spelling in formal writing I would suggest steering clear of it, as doing it consistently is likely to make a reader consider you to be lacking in formal education, or at least that you have some peculiar axe to grind.

No, the suffixes ‘self’ and ‘selves’ are only added to pronouns of possessive case to form a reflexive or emphatic pronouns; as, a) I hurt myself. (Reflexive Pronoun) b) I will do it myself. (Emphatic Pronoun) The word ‘me’ is a pronoun of objective case which is used as an (indirect) object of a transitive verb; as, a) She gave me her purse. b) They asked me a question.

You can! Just create a beautiful sentence around it, and stitch it with a beautiful story where colours are birds, and kids are teachers, a place where water is food and food is for all; but convince your reader that he or she is in a safe hand , and make sure that you are not ununderstood. If you don’t want to do that , like meself misunderstood it first , you should use “myself” instead.

As has already been answered, “meself" is incorrect and “myself" is correct English. Having said that, you will occasionally hear someone speaking slang, and saying what sounds like “meself". Even if you occasionally hear it said, it is not correct, and you would never write it.

There are dialects in which the reflexive pronoun corresponding to the standard ‘myself’ is ‘meself’. In those (nonstandard) dialects ‘meself’ is proper. If you are not speaking (or writing) such a dialect it is not.
You can write whatever you like, but “meself” is an extreme archaism that will arouse criticism and, perhaps, laughter. . . In pockets of the world, meself is still spoken.
It's either “me” or “myself”. I don't think meself is correct.

If you used this version within a sentence either spoken or written, then it would be assumed that you were representing a spoken dialect. The word does not properly exist in the English language and it can only be written as a phonetic representation of a spoken dialect word.
You can write it. But it is not a word.
